author: John Kehoe
title: US jobs gains hit stocks as investors raise bets on Fed rate rise
text:
Despite the persistent selling, the Dow is down just 2 per cent over the last seven trading days. Bloomberg Share on twitter Share on Google Plus by John Kehoe The US stock market sagged to its seventh straight losing session, as robust hiring figures heightened the case for the Federal Reserve to begin raising interest rates as soon as next month.
In further confirmation that the American expansion is on course, 215,000 jobs were added to the economy in July, data released on Friday showed, in line with Wall Street expectations.
The unemployment rate remained steady at 5.3 per cent, while wage inflation, which the Fed wants to see pick up, was still relatively subdued at 2.1 per cent.
Despite the improving economy, the blue chip Dow Jones Industrial Average fell on Friday, weighed down by investors positioning for a possible September interest rate hike and a slump in oil prices that smashed energy stocks.
Yields on shorter term US Treasury securities rose, as the bond market began to price in a September tightening by the Fed.
"This keeps the Fed on course to begin to lift short-term interest rates in September," Wells Fargo Securities senior economist Mark Vitner said.
That is far from a consensus view, with the bond market betting there is a 56 per cent chance of a Fed rate rise at the September 16-17 meeting and a 78 per cent likelihood before or during December, according to Bloomberg.
The Fed wants to see signs that stubbornly weak inflation will pick up before lifting rates.
 "Markets are highly data-dependent as they await the Fed," said Bank of America Merrill Lynch global economist Gustavo Reis.
The US dollar was mixed against various currencies, with the Australian dollar confounding the imminent US rate rise scenario and edging up to US74.12¢ on Saturday morning.
A host of popular US stocks have entered correction territory during the June quarter profit reporting season. Apple, Caterpillar, energy giant Exxon Mobil, IBM, Procter & Gamble and Walmart are among the blue chip names to have fallen 10 per cent or more from recent peaks.
American Express jumped more than 6 per cent on Friday, propped up by a Bloomberg report that said investment manager ValueAct Capital Management had built a $US1 billion stake – less than 5 per cent – in the credit card company.
The Dow Jones fell 0.27 per cent to 17,373.38, the S&P 500 Index eased 0.29 per cent to 2077.57, while the tech-heavy NASDAQ declined 0.26 per cent lower at 5043.54
Despite the persistent selling, the Dow is down just 2 per cent over the last seven trading days.
Nearing the end of US earnings season, second quarter earnings per share are down marginally, better than the expected 3.4 per cent decline tipped at the start of reporting, according to Wells Fargo Securities.
A slowdown in China and the surging US dollar are dragging on US multinational earnings.
Weighing on energy stocks, the price of Brent crude oil descended to $US48.63 a barrel on Friday in the US, down 1.8 per cent. Oil is plumbing its lowest price since January and has slumped 54 per cent over the past 12 months.
Investors this week dumped media and cable TV stocks including 21st Century Fox, Walt Disney and Viacom, as shareholders fretted about audiences switching from pay television to cheaper online streaming services like Netflix.
Despite the ongoing selling pressure in early August, the Dow Jones is down a relatively modest 5.3 per cent from its March peak.
Globally at the end of the week, German and French industrial production unexpectedly fell in June, pulling down European stock indexes.
The sombre mood around global stocks coincided with a savage 4 per cent sell off on the Australian Securities Exchange in the past week, as investors ditched banks over earnings concerns, increased provisions for bad debts and ANZ's $3 billion dilutionary capital raising.
In the week ahead, local investors will look to scheduled profit updates from Commonwealth Bank of Australia and Telstra.
Globally, investors will pore over profit results from Kraft Heinz, Noble Group, News Corp, Cisco Systems and Alibaba.
Key US economic data due for release include unit labour costs on Tuesday, retail sales on Thursday and industrial production on Friday.
